post_text: üì≤ www.2020census.gov/en.html
shared_text:
Fit X Brit
September 7 at 12:32 AM ¬∑

Time is winding down, but there is still time FOR YOU to take action. The streets have been talking heavily about the power of your vote, but if we want full representation in Dallas, we have to let our voices be heard by completing the Census so that we can all be counted. Our community's representation in Congress relies heavily on the number of people counted in each area and by taking the Census you are helping to change the narrative over the next 10 years. YUP 10 YEARS,

This is THE MOST Convenient Census Ever. Take the Census online, by phone, or by mail. Quick and simple.No need to leave home. Whether online, by telephone, or by mail, the only steps you need to take are on the census form. Take the Census now. https://2020census.gov/en.html #DallasCounts2020 dallascounts2020 #ad

September 13 at 9:32 PM ¬∑

Founded by a teacher 20 years ago, our priority is to get teachers what they need where they need it. Next Wednesday, September 16, starting at 7am EDT, donations to all projects on our site will be matched 50% in honor of our 20th anniversary.

Whether you're teaching from home or in the classroom, we'll send supplies exactly where you need them. #DonorsChoose20

Username: Your child‚Äôs seven-digit student identification number

Password: The letter ‚ÄúS‚Äù followed by the seven-digit student identification number

If it asks for an email, it's your child‚Äôs seven-digit student identification number @DallasISD.org

Each high school has slightly different login instructions for students, and the parent should have received that information through SchoolMessenger or an email.

post_text:
Based on the recent leveling out of Dallas County COVID-19 cases, the district is permitting the phased-in start of athletic conditioning and other designated UIL activities beginning Sept. 8. Current plans call for the athletic activities to occur outdoors.

The schedule for the restart of athletic activities is as follows:

‚ÄìTuesday, September 8, 2020 ‚Äì Varsity ONLY for the following sports: cross-country, football, golf, swimming, team tennis, and volleyball.

‚Äì Monday, September 14, 2020 ‚Äì Sub-varsity (9th grade and JV) for the following sports: cross-country, football, golf, swimming, team tennis, and volleyball

‚Äì Monday, September 21, 2020 ‚Äì UIL marching band, drill team, and cheerleading
shared_text:
THEHUB.DALLASISD.ORG
Dallas ISD is pivoting to phased-in athletic and related UIL activities

Based on the recent leveling out of Dallas County COVID-19 cases, the district is permitting the phased-in start of athletic conditioning and other designated UIL activities beginning Sept. 8. Current plans call for the athletic activities to occur outdoors.

The schedule for the restart of athletic activities is as follows:

‚ÄìTuesday, September 8, 2020 ‚Äì Varsity ONLY for the following sports: cross-country, football, golf, swimming, team tennis, and volleyball.

‚Äì Monday, September 14, 2020 ‚Äì Sub-varsity (9th grade and JV) for the following sports: cross-country, football, golf, swimming, team tennis, and volleyball

‚Äì Monday, September 21, 2020 ‚Äì UIL marching band, drill team, and cheerleading

post_text:
A BIG thank you to the Dallas Mavericks for pledging a $1 million personal protective equipment donation to Dallas ISD!

The PPE donation for every student (155,000), teacher (12,000), and staff member (12,000) in Dallas ISD includes reusable masks, face shields, hand sanitizer pumps, personal hand sanitizer units, and antibacterial wipes.
text:
A BIG thank you to the Dallas Mavericks for pledging a $1 million personal protective equipment donation to Dallas ISD!

The PPE donation for every student (155,000), teacher (12,000), and staff member (12,000) in Dallas ISD includes reusable masks, face shields, hand sanitizer pumps, personal hand sanitizer units, and antibacterial wipes.

Sadly, an old social media post from Jan. 26, 2017 has recirculated. The former employee was immediately placed on leave and never returned to a classroom in the district. The individual has not been employed by Dallas ISD since 2017.

Below is only an initial story published by the Dallas Morning News: https://www.dallasnews.com/news/2017/01/26/dallas-isd-suspends-adamson-teacher-over-faux-assassination-of-trump-with-water-gun/

post_text:
Today is the final day of Dallas ISD‚Äôs distribution of Grab & Go meals. There will not be meal service on Sept. 3, and curbside meal pickup service will resume Sept. 10 for registered district students.

All of Dallas ISD thanks the dozens of generous volunteers who helped our Dallas ISD Food & Child Nutrition Services team serve more than 8 million meals since the start of the coronavirus crisis. Your service was indispensable! Volunteers are still needed to assist with technology distribution at elementary schools to prepare students for distance learning.

To sign up for future volunteer opportunities, visit www.dallasisd.voly.org to register as a new or returning volunteer.

text:
A BIG thank you to the amazing Amazon.com volunteers who assisted Seagoville Elementary staff during today's Technology Deployment!

In addition to handing out devices to families, Amazon provided food and entertainment; all while respecting recommended physical-distancing guidelines. Thank you, Amazon!

post_text:
üì¶ Amazon volunteers are assisting Seagoville Elementary staff during their Technology Deployment.

On Monday, 20 volunteers helped plan the event, handed out devices to families and provided food and entertainment; all while respecting recommended physical-distancing guidelines.

üë©‚Äçüíª Approximately 700 Seagoville Elementary students will have district-provided iPads and Chromebooks to start school virtually on September 8th.

Additionally, around Amazon 40 volunteers preloaded essential software, installed outer protectors and packed backpacks with these devices, Saturday.

ü§ù Thank you for your contributions to our community, Amazon.com !

post_text:
Superintendent Hinojosa just announced that after consulting with his senior leadership & county health officials, the district will open with 100% distance learning when school starts Sept. 8. Distance learning continues through at least Oct. 6.

The decision reflects the guidance provided by Dallas County Health and Human Services. In addition, all extracurricular activities will remain in a distance setting as well, including strength and conditioning, band and drill team, all UIL and visual and performing arts activities.
text:
Superintendent Hinojosa just announced that after consulting with his senior leadership & county health officials, the district will open with 100% distance learning when school starts Sept. 8. Distance learning continues through at least Oct. 6.

The decision reflects the guidance provided by Dallas County Health and Human Services. In addition, all extracurricular activities will remain in a distance setting as well, including strength and conditioning, band and drill team, all UIL and visual and performing arts activities.

Yesterday, more than 600 Dallas ISD educators attended a webinar on ‚ÄúSelf-Care, Healing, & Equity-Responsive Practices When the World Feels Heavy‚Äù led by Dena Simmons, Ed.D., Assistant Director of the Yale Center for Emotional Intelligence.

This webinar was put on by SEL Dallas and explored self-care strategies to help staff cope with isolation, uncertainty, burnout, as well as the collective traumas of COVID-19 and America‚Äôs reckoning with race.

- Start date moves from Aug. 17, 2020, to Sept. 8, 2020.
- Removal of holidays in October due to State Fair Cancellation.
- Addition of holiday on Tuesday, Nov. 3, 2020.
- Change from six-week grading periods to nine-week grading periods.
- End date moves from May 27, 2021, to June 18, 2021.

View the board agenda here ‚û°Ô∏è https://bit.ly/3eMo7wr

This meeting will be shared via Facebook Live.

Pending the approval of the 2020 Bond, Dallas ISD will build Student & Family Resource Centers within the Lincoln, Roosevelt, Pinkston, and Spruce feeder patterns. The centers will host programs and services designed to improve student performance and address community needs. This is where your input comes in ‚Äì what amenities and services would improve your community and quality of life?

Please complete the survey on our website at www.dallasisd.org/resourcecenters.

post_text: COVID-19 requires school districts to be innovative and flexible as education is being reimagined around the globe. Dallas ISD is closely monitoring this ever-changing landscape and will continue to work with the Texas Education Agency as we prepare to safely reopen schools. The health and safety of all students and staff is always our top priority. Understandably, many parents, teachers, and staff have questions and Dallas ISD is working to identify the best strategies with their interests in mind. The Board of Trustees will convene later this month for a special called meeting at which time, the administration may make recommendations for an alternative start date for the 2020-2021 school year.
text: COVID-19 requires school districts to be innovative and flexible as education is being reimagined around the globe. The health and safety of all students and staff is always our top priority. Understandably, many parents, teachers, and staff have questions and Dallas ISD is working to identify the best strategies with their interests in mind. The Board of Trustees will convene later this month for a special called meeting at which time, the administration may make recommendations for an alternative start date for the 2020-2021 school year.

post_text:
Join SEL Dallas next Monday, July 6, at 9 am and 1 pm for a live online reading session of "Let the Children March" by Monica Clark-Robinson.

In 1963 Birmingham, Alabama, thousands of African American children volunteered to march for their civil rights after hearing Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. speak. Facing fear, hate, and danger, these children used their voices to change the world. Readings will take place via a secure Zoom link, which will be shared in your confirmation email.

Register on Eventbrite! ‚¨áÔ∏è
shared_text:

Dallas Let's Read Let the Children March by Monica Clark-Robinson

Join SEL Dallas next Monday, July 6, at 9 am and 1 pm for a live online reading session of "Let the Children March" by Monica Clark-Robinson.

In 1963 Birmingham, Alabama, thousands of African American children volunteered to march for their civil rights after hearing Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. speak. Facing fear, hate, and danger, these children used their voices to change the world. Readings will take place via a secure Zoom link, which will be shared in your confirmation email.

post_text: Update: Governor Abbott and HHSC have extended the P-EBT deadline from June 30 to July 31!
shared_text:
DALLASISD.ORG
Food & Child Nutrition Services / P-EBT Benefits

Dallas ISD
June 29 at 12:53 AM ¬∑

Because Dallas ISD offers free meals to all its students, all families are eligible to receive the Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT), a one-time benefit provided by the State of Texas for eligible families to buy food.

The P-EBT of $285 per child is available for families that may have temporarily lost access to free and reduced-price meals because of school closures due to COVID-19. The amount is based on the average number of days schools are closed for the remainder of the school year.

Students from Trinidad Garza Early College High School share their personal experiences in ‚ÄúFaceless: Untold Side Effects of Culture, Race & COVID-19," a published anthology.

‚ÄúThis project gives voice to an incredibly resilient generation of students who are navigating one of the most unprecedented times in our history. Their written words are rooted in their own lived experiences regarding issues of race, culture, and the global pandemic." -Principal Macario Hernadez

post_text:
LaTrisha McDuffie, SEL Specialist from Big Thought, gives us three challenges to help you take care of yourself as we are watching change unfold in front of our eyes.
‚Å†
1. Celebrate Black Lives!
2. Complete the 2020 Census!
3. Register to Vote!
shared_text:
SEL Dallas
June 10 at 3:01 PM ¬∑

It‚Äôs up to all of us ‚Äì Black, white, everyone ‚Äì no matter how well-meaning we think we might be, to do the honest, uncomfortable work of rooting it out. - Michelle Obama

It's Big on Self Care! Every Wednesday join SEL Specialist, Latrisha McDuffie, as she demonstrates some easy ways we can take care of ourselves at home. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Today LaTrisha McDuffie takes us on a Self Care Scavenger Hunt themed "We Are Not Okay!‚Äù She gives us three challenges to do that are designed to help you take care of yourself as we are watching change unfold in front of our eyes.
‚Å†
1. Celebrate Black Lives!
2. Complete the 2020 Census!
3. Register to Vote!
https://vimeo.com/427744835

Also be sure to check out other at home SEL experiences by visiting https://seldallas.org/sel-dallas-virtual-learning-resources/‚Å†
‚Å†
‚Å†
#SELDallas #KeepDallasKind #DallasISD #socialemotionallearning #distancelearning #socialskills #emotionalintelligence #distancelearning #becreative #creativity #athomelearning #stayathome #workfromhome

post_text:
Why are Dallas ISD playgrounds closed and when will these reopen?

To help flatten the curve of COVID-19 infections and protect our children and families, the Dallas Independent School District has closed its campuses and facilities, including our playgrounds. We will begin to open our facilities and playgrounds as state, county and medical officials lift the stay-at-home restrictions. Our hope is that we can reopen all facilities sooner rather than later as the county returns to normal. Thank you for your understanding and patience during this unprecedented and trying
text:
Why are Dallas ISD playgrounds closed and when will these reopen?

To help flatten the curve of COVID-19 infections and protect our children and families, the Dallas Independent School District has closed its campuses and facilities, including our playgrounds. We will begin to open our facilities and playgrounds as state, county and medical officials lift the stay-at-home restrictions. Our hope is that we can reopen all facilities sooner rather than later as the county returns to normal. Thank you for your understanding and patience during this unprecedented and trying

post_text: This Friday, March 27, the nonprofit Carter‚Äôs House will distribute free diapers, wipes, socks and underwear to expectant parents and families with children ages 0 to 3. post_text:
At-home learning will begin tomorrow for all Dallas ISD students, including those in a PTECH/Collegiate Academy/Early College High School program.

However, these students will NOT need to attend their respective Dallas County Community College District campus. Instead, their dual credit courses will resume Monday, March 30 also through on-line teaching.

We appreciate your support as we continue to create alternative instructional options for our students, in an effort to help slow spread of coronavirus.
text:
At-home learning will begin tomorrow for all Dallas ISD students, including those in a PTECH/Collegiate Academy/Early College High School program.

However, these students will NOT need to attend their respective Dallas County Community College District campus. Instead, their dual credit courses will resume Monday, March 30 also through on-line teaching.

We appreciate your support as we continue to create alternative instructional options for our students, in an effort to help slow spread of coronavirus.

üèà Spruce High School athletes got a surprise during Wednesday‚Äôs after-school practice: Their weight-room had been completely renovated!

ü§ù The Cal Ripken, Sr. Foundation and UnitedHealthcare‚Äôs partner every year to upgrade training spaces in schools across the country.

üõ† Volunteers disassembled and removed old equipment, installed new flooring, hung graphics and whiteboards, cleaned and built new storage solutions, and assembled and installed new fitness equipment. They also cleaned, painted and assembled new furniture in the teacher and student lounges.

üèãÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Chris Welsh, a nationally renowned trainer worked with Spruce coaches to design the new space. The upgraded weight-room and gym was unveiled to the students.
